origin: Old English open (adjective), openian (verb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch open and German offen, from the root of the adverb up.

definitions.definition: Allowing access, passage, or a view through an empty space; not closed or blocked up.
definitions.example: the pass is kept open all year by snowplows

definitions.definition: Exposed to the air or to view; not covered.
definitions.example: an open fire burned in the grate

definitions.definition: With the outer edges or sides drawn away from each other; unfolded.
(of a store, place of entertainment, etc.) officially admitting customers or visitors; available for business.
definitions.example: the store stays open until 9 p.m.

definitions.definition: Freely available or accessible; offered without restriction.
definitions.example: the service is open to all students at the university

definitions.definition: (of a person) frank and communicative; not given to deception or concealment.
definitions.example: I was quite open about my views
synonyms: not afraid to call a spade a spade

definitions.definition: (of a question, case, or decision) not finally settled; still admitting of debate.
definitions.example: students' choice of major can be kept open until the second year

definitions.definition: (of a note) sounded from an open string or pipe.
definitions.example: He provides a great deal of hard information about transposing brass instruments, such as hand horns crooked in different keys to give a maximum of open notes.

definitions.definition: (of a string) allowed to vibrate along its whole length.
definitions.example: You can learn how to use an open string to give a reference tone when playing the fiddle.

definitions.definition: (of an electrical circuit) having a break in the conducting path.
definitions.example: No or low output voltage means the transformer winding has open or shorted winding.

definitions.definition: (of a vowel) produced with a relatively wide opening of the mouth and the tongue kept low.
Move or adjust (a door or window) so as to leave a space allowing access and view.
definitions.example: she opened the door and went in

definitions.definition: Unfold or be unfolded; spread out.
definitions.example: the eagle opened its wings and circled up into the air

definitions.definition: Establish (a new business, movement, or enterprise)
definitions.example: they have opened a new restaurant across the street

definitions.definition: Make or become officially ready for customers, visitors, or business.
definitions.example: one woman raised $731 by opening her home and selling coffee and tea

definitions.definition: Make available or more widely known.
definitions.example: new technologies open up thousands of different opportunities

definitions.definition: Break the conducting path of (an electrical circuit)
definitions.example: the switch opens the motor circuit

definitions.definition: A championship or competition with no restrictions on who may qualify to compete.
definitions.example: the venue for the British Open

definitions.definition: An accidental break in the conducting path for an electrical current.
definitions.example: An open in a wire prevents the propagation of a signal past the open.
